fields.description:
I think it is incorrect behavior for Eucalyptus to modify the semantics of an environment variable it doesn't "own", in this case, modification of the AWS_DEFAULT_REGION environment variable to prepend "USER@" to specify the user in addition to the region when looking up Euca2ools credentials.

This BREAKS the simultaneous use of AWS CLI against either Eucalyptus or AWS regions, as the AWS CLI uses this variable to lookup endpoints, and when the "USER@" prefix is present, all commands fail.

Because Euca2ools does not currently support S3, and because we have a current and increasing need to support hybrid use cases which may require use of AWS CLI for S3 in parallel with Euca2ools, or instead of Euca2ools because we're using existing customer scripts based on AWS when repatriating, I think we need to fix this.

I have some suggestions, which I've already raised to Garrett in various personal conversations, but would like to document for the record here.

* Add a "--profile" or "--user" argument to all commands, and use this to pass the USER value. Obtain the value from this via the existing AWS_DEFAULT_PROFILE environment variable, which would match how AWS CLI works. Alternatively, we can have a EUCA_DEFAULT_USER environment variable for this (more on this below). We can continue to support the USER@REGION syntax on the --region argument and AWS_DEFAULT_REGION env var, but I think it should be deprecated - as stated in my opening, I don't think it's "right" to change how a variable we don't "own" works. I know this breaks AWSCLI - I don't know what else it might break in hybrid use cases.
* Inside Euca2ools [user] section in configuration .ini files, have a "region = <region>" reference to indicate the default region for the user. This matches how AWS CLI profiles work, where users reference a default region, contrasted against the current Euca2ools behavior where each [region] can reference a default user. I think this gets the relationship backward, as there is generally a M:1 relationship between Users:Regions, and it's not always easy to pick one default user for a region. I think this will become more of an issue as we start to see federated Eucalyptus installs, where a single federated user might have a default region in which they normally create assets, similar to the situation with AWS now. This would allow us to only set the --profile argument, or only set the AWS_DEFAULT_PROFILE env var and have the default region obtained via this reference, again same way AWSCLI works, and what AWS users are going to be most familiar with.
* Have matched sets of AWS_DEFAULT_PROFILE / EUCA_DEFAULT_PROFILE, AWS_DEFAULT_REGION / EUCA_DEFAULT REGION, etc as needed, environment variables, where if both are set, Euca2ools prefers the value with the EUCA_ prefix. Since AWS CLI is not aware of the EUCA_ prefix, we could then use both sets of environment variables in parallel more easily. The "USER@" prefix could continue to be supported for EUCA_DEFAULT_REGION, for example, while we could use AWS_DEFAULT_PROFILE to set the USER and AWS_DEFAULT_REGION without the USER@ to define the REGION with AWS CLI in parallel without the problem I've hit.
* Have Euca2ools first look for any [user] and [region] definitions within the current configuration hierarchy consisting of ~/.euca, /etc/euca2ools/ /etc/euca2ools/conf.d, but if a [user] value is not found, have it continue to look for the USER value as a [profile USER] in ~/.aws/config or [USER] in ~/.aws/credentials. In use-cases where we are using AWSCLI instead of, or in addition to Euca2ools, this would prevent the need to create duplicate user credentials in two locations. We would only have to define the Euca region endpoints specifically for Euca within Euca2ools configuration files. Note we would still have to modify the botocore "_endpoints.json" to specify the Euca Region endpoints to use AWSCLI. But once this config is done to define region endpoints, users would only have to be defined once. Ideally.

So, because of this problem, I had to develop a workaround to support stuff like the "WordPress AWS Repatriation demo", where a single script hits both AWS and Euca, and because of S3 commands to create/upload/download files, I am using either AWSCLI exclusively or a combination of Euca2ools and AWS CLI for S3 (I have both variants I can demo). I set AWS_DEFAULT_REGION to just the AWS or Euca REGION - this works with both AWSCLI and Euca2ools. I set AWS_DEFAULT_PROFILE to the USER, but this only works for AWSCLI. To specify the USER via the environment for Euca2ools in a way which doesn't break AWSCLI, I create a ~/.creds/$REGION/$ACCOUNT/$USER/iamrc file containing the access and secret key, then set AWS_CREDENTIAL_FILE to that path. This env var is used by Euca2ools when it exists to lookup the access/secret key, but is ignored by AWSCLI, so no conflict. However, this method ignores the Euca2ools [user] section, so it's not a great solution. In many cases, I'm forced to clear the environment and explicitly pass --region USER@REGION to Euca2ools commands and --profile USER --region REGION to AWSCLI to use them in parallel.

In summary, what's broken (IMHO) is one thing specifically: "USER@" prefix inside AWS_DEFAULT_REGION as the only method to specify a USER via the environment which uses the [user] information in Euca2ools configuration files. Any solution should allow me to specify both USER and REGION to Euca2ools in a manner which does not break parallel use of AWSCLI commands. Hopefully my suggestions on how to fix this are logical, but I'm open to anything which fixes this.

Would love to see this in 4.2.1!
fields.summary: Eucalyptus modifications to AWS_DEFAULT_REGION environment variable break AWS CLI

comments.body: Commit {{6e1a532}} adds a {{EUCA_DEFAULT_REGION}} environment variable that takes precedence over {{AWS_DEFAULT_REGION}} for use in cases where overloading the latter causes issues.

*Euca2ools Version* {{3.3.1-0.1820.50.20161115gitdc4f158.el7}} *Steps* # Set up Eucalyptus 4.3.1 cloud with VPC - [hspencer-207|http://jenkins.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com/job/Quick%20Launch%20Maint-4.3/207/] # Updated euca2ools using nightlies: {code} [root@d-14 ~]# yum install http://downloads.eucalyptus.com/software/euca2ools/nightly/devel/rhel/7/x86_64/euca2ools-release-nightly-0-1.el7.noarch.rpm -y [root@d-14 ~]# yum update euca2ools -y {code} # Set environment variables for {{AWS_DEFAULT_REGION}} and {{EUCA_DEFAULT_REGION}}: {code} [root@d-14 ~]# export AWS_DEFAULT_REGION=us-east-1 [root@d-14 ~]# export EUCA_DEFAULT_REGION=future [root@d-14 ~]# echo $AWS_DEFAULT_REGION us-east-1 [root@d-14 ~]# echo $EUCA_DEFAULT_REGION future {code} # Ran {{euca-describe-availability-zones}}: {code} [root@d-14 ~]# euca-describe-availability-zones --region qa-admin@ --debug 2016-12-08 07:15:42,774 DEBUG DescribeAvailabilityZones parsed arguments from CLI: {'filters': None, 'security_token': None, 'url': None, 'region': 'qa-admin@', 'show_empty_fields': False, 'key_id': None, 'secret_key': None, 'ZoneName': []} 2016-12-08 07:15:42,774 INFO Config set region to future 2016-12-08 07:15:42,774 INFO Config set user to qa-admin 2016-12-08 07:15:42,774
